variantrule.name: Called Shots
entries: Once per round, when you declare an {@action Attack|XPHB}, you can choose to make a Called Shot to impose specific effects on the target. The effect only applies if the targeted part qualifies under the following guidelines, subject to the DM's discretion.
If the effect requires a saving throw, the DC is determined by the attribute used for the attack roll.
If your Called Shot exceeds the target's AC by 5 or more, you may apply one of the following effects:

entries.name: Optional Rule. Martials Only!
entries: By default, Called Shots are intended to be used only by players (or NPCs with notable martial prowess) whose majority of levels are in Martial Classes (classes that gain Weapon Mastery).

entries.name: Movement Parts.
entries: Parts responsible for movement. Until the end of the creatures next turn, the creature’s speed associated with the part hitten is reduced by 10 feet.

entries.name: Weapon Parts
entries: Parts used as weapons. The creature have {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on the next attack roll it makes before the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Armor Parts
entries: Parts used to protect the user. On a failed Constitution saving throw, the creature’s AC is reduced by an amount based on the part's contribution until the end of its next turn. This does not apply to body armor of any sorts, as it 'passively' protects the body.

entries.name: Weak Point Parts
entries: Parts that are some type of vulnerability. Your attack deals an additional 1d10 damage of the same type.

entries.name: Special Ability Parts
entries: Parts responsible for a Special Ability. On a failed Constitution saving throw, the creature is unable to use that ability until the end of its next turn. The DM determines whether the Special Ability is fully or partially disabled.

entries.name: Utility Parts
entries: Parts used for utility or miscellaneous tasks. On a failed Constitution saving throw the part becomes impaired until the end of the creature's next turn. It impedes the target part to be used to activate magic items, performing somatic components (if hand), verbal components (if a mouth or jaw), use held items as components of spells, and impede speech (if a mouth or jaw).

If appropriate, the DM might apply this effect as a bonus to other effect. Targeting a dragon's jaw to impede its breath weapon (under Special Ability Parts) might apply this effect and impede its speech as well.

entries.caption: Examples of Targeted Body Parts
rows: Wings (affects flying speed), Legs (affects walking speed).
Arm holding a sword, Arms, Claws, Mouth (for bite attacks).
Existing injury, Soft spot in armor or carapace.
Jaw (disable Fire Breath for a Red Dragon), Eye stalk (disable Eye Ray for a Beholder), Throat (disable Wail for a Banshee), Face (disable Petrifying Gaze for a Medusa).

entries.name: Worn, Carried and Held Items
entries: You can target items being held, carried or worn by a creature. The object AC is the higher value between the item's AC and the creature's AC. Its HP is the higher value beetween half the creature's maximum HP or the items HP (see {@variantrule Breaking Objects|XPHB} for AC and HP of items). On a hit, you only deal damage to the item. If the item need to make a save, it doesn't automatically fail and use the creature's saving throw bonuses instead.
Magic items can only be damaged by items that have equal or stronger magic than itself. You can use the rarity as a guideline to determine the relative strength of a magic item.
Alternativaly, you can consider rarity to have a equivalency with spell levels. Like Common (1st level), Uncommon (3rd Level), Rare (6th Level), Very Rare (8th Level), and Legendary (9th Level)

variantrule.name: Non-Lethal Damage
entries: When making an attack roll or dealing damage with an effect that requires a saving throw (such as a spell), you can choose to make it non-lethal. In this case, if the creature would die as a result of the damage, it instead falls unconscious and follows the rules for death saving throws ({@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB}) rather than dying outright.

entries.name: Optional Rule: It's Hard to Spare Lives
entries: When attempting a non-lethal attack or effect that requires a saving throw using this rule, your attack roll is made with disadvantage, and if the effect involves a saving throw, the target has advantage on its saving throw. This reflects the difficulty of subduing a target without dealing fatal damage and may make capturing enemies more challenging.

variantrule.name: Rarity Rules for Shops
entries: <script>function testeFuncao() { console.log('Função Rodou!'); alert('Função Rodou!'); }</script>
<!--<button onclick="testeFuncao()">TESTE</button> -->

items: Common: These shops typically stock simple mundane items and may carry Common magical items.
Uncommon: These shops feature high-quality mundane items and may include Uncommon magical items.

Rare: These shops provide exceptional mundane items and may stock impactful Rare magical items. In most places, this represents the highest-tier market accessible, with prices well beyond the means of commoners.
Very Rare: These shops offer the finest magical items, often of Very Rare quality, with occasional Legendary items.
Legendary: These shops are either multiplanar megastores with extensive inventories or exclusive boutiques specializing in legendary-quality goods.

entries: Shop types include {@table Shop List: Grocery|CompendiumofAcadia|Grocery}, {@table Shop List: Cloth Shop|CompendiumofAcadia|Cloth Shop}, {@table Shop List: Forge|CompendiumofAcadia|Forge}, {@table Shop List: Alchemy Lab|CompendiumofAcadia|Alchemy Lab}, {@table Shop List: General Store|CompendiumofAcadia|General Store}, {@table Shop List: Arcane Shop|CompendiumofAcadia|Arcane Shop}, {@table Shop List: Jewelry Shop|CompendiumofAcadia|Jewelry Shop}, {@table Shop List: Inn|CompendiumofAcadia|Inn}, {@table Shop List: Herbal Shop|CompendiumofAcadia|Herbal Shop}, {@table Shop List: Exotic Emporium|CompendiumofAcadia|Exotic Emporium}, {@table Shop List: Stable|CompendiumofAcadia|Stable}, {@table Shop List: Library|CompendiumofAcadia|Library}, {@table Shop List: Workshop|CompendiumofAcadia|Workshop}, {@table Shop List: Bank|CompendiumofAcadia|Bank}, {@table Shop List: Guildhall|CompendiumofAcadia|Guildhall}, and {@table Shop List: Courier Office|CompendiumofAcadia|Courier Office}.

Higher-quality shops typically do not stock lower-quality items. For example, Rare shops are unlikely to sell Common items. However, item tables for different rarities can be combined to represent shops that cater to a broader range of needs (e.g., merging Rare and Common shop tables).

Shops that sell items of set rarity often have the capacity to fabricate items of set rarity, and such items may be commissioned. Crafting times and costs follow the {@table Magic Item Crafting Time and Cost|XDMG} guidelines based on item rarity. Crafting speed may be increased by 1 to 5 times at the DM's discretion, depending on the resources and effort allocated. However, this may also increase costs by a similar multiplier if the shop prioritizes your project over others.

variantrule.name: Destroying Magical Barriers, and Similars
entries: Magical barriers, force creatures, and similar effects, such as Leomund's Tiny Hut, Tiny Servant, Arcane Gate, Wall of Force, Mordenkainen's Faithful Hound, and Arcane Eye, can be destroyed using magical weapons.
HP and AC: These effects have hit points equal to 20 times the spell level of their creation and an AC of 20. They are immune to Poison and Psychic damage, and fails all saving throws.

Destruction: Only magic weapons can damage them, with the required rarity depending on the spell level: Common (1st-level), Uncommon (3rd-level), Rare (6th-level), Very Rare (8th-level), and Legendary (9th-level).
DM Discretion: The DM may rule that some effects are more resistant or immune to specific magical effects or items.

variantrule.name: Coup de Grace
entries: You can use your action to attempt to execute a {@condition Unconscious|XPHB} or {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB} creature. Make an attack roll that automatically hits. Roll 1d4 to determine the outcome:

items: On a roll of 1–3, the creature dies instantly.
On a roll of 4, the creature takes the normal damage from the attack instead of dying.

entries: If the target is a player character or an important NPC, it only instantly dies on a roll of a 4. Otherwise, it takes the normal damage from the attack.

entries.name: Optional Rule: Cinematic Only!
entries: The Coup de Grace can only be used in scenes outside of combat.

variantrule.name: Fight For the Fallen
entries: When a character dies in battle, if they have enough memories with their allies who are still fighting (at the DM's discretion), they may inspire their allies to continue battling in their name. The fallen character remains in the initiative order, and takes a Fallen Action at the start of their turn until the battle ends. If the character cannot invoke an appropriate memory, they lose their Fallen Action for that turn without any effect.
This are the Fallen Actions:

items: Remember Me: The fallen ally's memory inspires. The Fallen character narrates a meaningful past scene with one ally who is still fighting, granting that ally a Bardic Inspiration die. The die size depends on the Fallen character's level: 1d6 (below level 5), 1d8 (level 5-9), 1d10 (level 10-14), or 1d12 (level 15+).
Keep My Memory: The memory of fighting side by side grants resilience. The Fallen character narrates a scene of camaraderie, healing an ally for 1d10 + the Fallen character's level in hit points.

Full Speed Ahead: The memory of their ally's unyielding determination pushes them forward. The Fallen character narrates a moment of drive and determination, allowing one ally to immediately move up to their speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

Suffering: The fallen ally's pain and sacrifice ignite a fiery resolve. The Fallen character narrates a moment of shared struggle, granting an ally resistance to all damage until the start of their next turn.

Not Sorry For Loving: The bond of love romantic, or fraternal fuels one final push. The Fallen character narrates a deeply emotional memory of love and care, granting an ally an extra Action on their next turn. This action ends the Fight For the Fallen state for the character as the spirit departs with a final shared moment of triumph.

Last Laugh: The memory of camaraderie inspires all allies to their fullest. The Fallen character narrates a moment of humor or victory they all had together, granting all allies in battle the effects of 'Remember Me,' 'Keep My Memory,' 'Full Speed Ahead,' or 'Suffering.' This action ends the Fight For the Fallen state for the character as the spirit departs with a final shared triumph.

entries: A character can only enter the Fight For the Fallen state once.

variantrule.name: Precarious Recovery
entries: A creature with 0 hit points has the following rules:

items: It can only regain hit points if it is {@variantrule Stable|XPHB}.
If it would regain 5 or more hit points, it becomes {@variantrule Stable|XPHB} instead of healing. Healing for less than 5 hit points has no effect.
Rolling a natural 20 on a {@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XScreen|death saving throw} causes it to become {@variantrule Stable|XPHB} and restore 1 hit point afterwards.

variantrule.name: Death's Door
entries: This rule assumes the use of Precarious Recovery (See {@variantrule Precarious Recovery|CompendiumofAcadia}).

When reduced to 0 hit points, a character can choose to enter Death's Door instead of falling {@condition Unconscious|XPHB}. While at Death's Door, the character remains conscious but is at significant risk of death.
The creature is in extreme distress, exhibiting signs of partial insanity such as speaking gibberish, uttering nonsensical phrases, or experiencing minor hallucinations.
While at Death's Door, the following rules apply:

items: At the start of its turn, the creature chooses whether to fall {@condition Unconscious|XPHB}, ending Death's Door and following the standard rules for a creature at 0 hit points.
The creature is treated as having 0 hit points (see {@variantrule Death Saving Throws|XScreen}).
At the end of each turn, the creature gains one level of exhaustion.
Death's Door ends immediately if the creature regains any hit points.

entries: A creature can only enter Death's Door once per {@variantrule Short Rest|XPHB|Short} or {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

variantrule.name: Acadian Magic Rebalancing
entries: This section outlines changes, rebalancing, additions, and bans on spells for Acadia. These adjustments assume the use of the {@variantrule Alternate Spell Casting|CompendiumofAcadia}.
If a spell with the same name exists in the 2024 Player's Handbook (PHB) and another source, the 2024 PHB takes precedence. In other cases, the Dungeon Master (DM) determines which version to use.

Spells from the following books are accepted: Player's Handbook 2024, Acquisitions Incorporated, Astral Adventurer's Guide, Fizban's Treasury of Dragons, Guildmasters' Guide to Ravnica, Icewind Dale: Rime of the Frostmaiden, Strixhaven: A Curriculum of Chaos, Tasha's Cauldron of Everything, The Book of Many Things, Xanathar's Guide to Everything, Dungeons of Drakkenheim, Tal'Dorei Campaign Setting Reborn, Humblewood Campaign Setting, Grim Hollow: Lairs of Etharis, Explorer's Guide to Wildemount, Lost Laboratory of Kwalish, The Gunpowder Codex, and Firearms of the Realms.

Buffs focus on improving underperforming spells to make them more impactful. Reworks aim to streamline spell functionality (e.g., changing {@spell Blade Ward|CompendiumofAcadia} to grant +2 AC instead of imposing a -1d4 penalty on attack rolls against the target).

Nerfs target spells with unusual scaling, 'save-or-suck' mechanics, or those that enable revivals, counter curses, or exploits that disrupt balance. Some spells are adjusted to avoid overshadowing existing options or to maintain high fantasy settings without introducing overly complex implications.

Bans primarily apply to excessively powerful spells that conflict with the intended tone or gameplay balance of the world. Added spells include those related to Pathfinders, Acadia Homebrew or substitutes for existing spells.

entries.name: Additional Notes
entries: Mechanics Added or Changed:

rows: Inefficiency Compensation. This cost offsets the spell's inherent inefficiency. Alternatively, you may expend an additional spell slot of the spell's level or a 4th-level spell slot (whichever is lower) to bypass this cost when casting the spell.

Royalty Component. This fee applies only when casting the spell within a plane where the creator holds a franchise. If cast elsewhere, the restriction is lifted, and the additional cost is ignored.
Instead of making a DC 15 Intelligence (Arcana) check to make another random creature pay the Royalty, the creature must make an Intelligence Saving Throw against the spell save DC.

variantrule.name: Acadian
entries: As an Acadian, you are a student of the most prestigious and powerful school in the entire manyverse. Here, you gain access to items of unparalleled power that cannot be found anywhere else.

As an Acadian, you are a force that shapes the manyverse itself. Your presence cannot be easily swayed, as your ability to alter the course of history across the planes is nothing short of world-changing. Through your actions, new pantheons may emerge, planes and worlds may be permanently connected, gods may be forged, and entire species might be created. Of course, such feats require mastery and time, attainable only by those who have tapped into the essence of how the manyverse operates.
As an Acadian, you gain access to the Acadian Epic Boons, designed to be learned at The Second Acadia School of Magic.
You may also acquire specific feats, such as {@feat Acadian Latent Power|CompendiumofAcadia}.
If you are a Pathfinder—one of the top students—you gain access to additional feats like {@feat World Traveler|CompendiumofAcadia} and {@feat Cosmopolitan|CompendiumofAcadia}.

variantrule.name: Pathfinder
entries: As a Pathfinder, you were born with an innate and powerful ability to tap into the essence of the manyverse, perceive other worlds, and travel through them.

While your abilities are extraordinary, they require time and mastery to fully develop. As a Pathfinder, you gain the Epic Boon {@feat World Traveler|CompendiumofAcadia} and access to the {@variantrule Pathfinder Mana System|CompendiumofAcadia}.

variantrule.name: Unshaped Class
entries: You begin at level 1 as an Unshaped character with the Unshaped Class, a flexible starting state that allows you to transition into a specific class later. Use the following guidelines to create your Unshaped character:

entries.name: Unshaped Core Traits
entries: Primary Ability: None
Hit Points: 6 + your Constitution modifier
Weapon Proficiencies: Simple weapons
Proficiency Bonus: +2
Starting Attributes: 14, 14, 12, 12, 10, 8
Starting Equipment: One or two simple weapons of your choice, an Explorer's Pack, common clothes, one common or uncommon magic item, and 10 GP.

entries.name: Creating Your Character
entries: 1. Choose a Race: Select a race as per standard character creation rules.
2. Choose a Background: Pick a background for your character to determine skills, tools, and features.

entries.name: Unshaped Luck
entries: As an Unshaped character, you possess a unique ability reflecting your fluid and adaptable nature. When you make a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, you can grant yourself {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on the roll. Alternatively, when a creature makes an attack roll against you, you can impose {@variantrule Disadvantage|XPHB} on that roll.
You can use this feature twice, and you regain all expended uses when you finish a Short or Long Rest.

entries.name: Gaining a Class Level
entries: When an Unshaped character levels up, they replace their 1st level with the 1st level of another class, signifying their transition into a specialized role. Follow these steps:
1. Replace your 'Unshaped Luck' feature with either an Ability Score Improvement or another feat of your choice for which you qualify.
2. Gain all 1st-level features of the chosen class, except for starting equipment. Adjust your proficiencies, saving throws, and other abilities as per the class rules.
3. Replace your current hit points with the hit points granted at 1st level by the chosen class.

variantrule.name: Wheel of Destiny
entries: Some heroes rise and fall, but the Wheel of Destiny keeps spinning, weaving tales yet untold. Fear not! There is always a hero for the stories to find their voice!

The Wheel of Destiny is a mystical game of fate, played by beings of immense power to guide stories and influence the tides of destiny. In essence, it is a deck of cards, The Deck of Destiny, that channels the will of fate for those it deems worthy.
At the start of each session, players draw a card from the Deck of Destiny. At the end of the session, all cards are returned to the deck, and it is shuffled for the next cycle.

entries.name: Deck of Destiny Composition
entries: To use this mechanic, you’ll need a deck of playing cards. Assemble the deck as follows:
- 7 cards from each suit (Hearts, Diamonds, Clubs, Spades): 8, 9, 10, J (Jack), Q (Queen), K (King), and Aces.
- Add 1 Joker.
This creates a custom 29-card deck for the Wheel of Destiny. Shuffle the deck after arranging it.

entries.name: Activation Rules
entries: Destiny Cards can be activated at any time. The player, not the character, activates the card. This means cards can still be used even if the character is unconscious or dead. If the GM allow, it can even be used in scenes where the player character is not present.
Instead of using the suit's effect, players may choose an effect from the 'Essential Use' list.
After activation, the card is placed in the discard pile. Once all cards have been used, a {@variantrule Wheel Of Destiny Spin|CompendiumofAcadia} occurs, and the deck is restored.

items: Heal twice the card’s value; or
Make a weapon attack (Aces grant an additional action instead of an attack); or
Gain temporary {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level (round up), expiring after a Long Rest.
Add the card’s value as a bonus to any d20 Test; or
Recover a spell slot up to 4th level (Aces recover a spell slot of any level); or
Gain temporary {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level (round up), expiring after a Long Rest.
After a creature takes damage, add damage equal to the card's value of the same type; or
Give disadvantage to a d20 Test made by a creature you can see (Aces make the creature roll an additional d20 and take the lowest result); or
Gain temporary {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level (round up), expiring after a Long Rest.
Increase your AC by half the card's value (rounded down) until the end of this turn; or
Gain resistance to a damage type until the end of this turn (Aces grant resistance to all damage types); or
Gain temporary {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level (round up), expiring after a Long Rest.
After knowing the result of a d20 Test, make it fail; or
Choose a specific result for a Luck Roll; or
Gain 1 temporary {@variantrule 🟣 Purple Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, lasting until the end of this turn.
Replace a d20 Test made by you with the card’s value (declare before rolling); or
Gain a {@variantrule Heroic Inspiration|XPHB}; or
Gain temporary {@variantrule 🔵 Blue Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} equal to half your level (round up), expiring after a Long Rest.

variantrule.name: Wheel Of Destiny Spin
entries:
A Roda do Destino Gira.
Nem para frente, nem para trás—apenas envolta de si.

Uma vez posta em movimento, ela se afina.
Cada volta estica o fio,
Mais fino, mais afiado, mais forte.

O pincel do destino mergulha em tinta gasta,
Tinta pesada, espessa, endurecida.
As possibilidades secam e se estreitam.
O que antes fluía livre, agora penetra fundo,
Cada camada mais escura, mais densa, e mais implacável.

As escolhas se comprimem. O poder se condensa.
Os fracos se espalham; os fortes se afinam.

Gire novamente.
Desgire.
Pode a Roda aliviar seu peso?
Pode ela se soltar, voltar a engrossar?

Você não pode quebrá-la. Você não pode detê-la.
Ela gira.
E gira você.

O fim é onde termina
Movimento absoluto.

variantrule.name: 🟣 Purple Mana
Deadly Falls
entries: Tiny creatures use d4s for falling damage, Small and Medium creatures use d6s, Large creatures use d8s, Huge creatures use d10s, and Gargantuan creatures use d12s per 10 feet fallen. Falling damage is capped at 50 dice. For example, a Small or Medium creature falling 100 feet takes 10d6 (max 50d6), while a Gargantuan creature falling the same distance takes 10d12 (max 50d12).

variantrule.name: Additional Conditions
entries: This introduces new conditions:

items: {@condition Ablaze|CompendiumofAcadia}
{@condition Steeled|CompendiumofAcadia}
{@condition Confused|CompendiumofAcadia}
{@condition Oiled|CompendiumofAcadia}
{@condition Drenched|CompendiumofAcadia}

variantrule.name: Additional Feats
entries: This introduces new feats:

items: {@feat Mage Catcher|CompendiumofAcadia}

variantrule.name: Pathfinder Mana System
entries: A creature with access to the Pathfinder Mana System must choose two mana types to have an affinity with. This choice reflects their themes and identity. For example, a Paladin obsessed with law and driven by passion to overcome obstacles might have an affinity for {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} and {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}.

Once chosen, mana affinities cannot be changed except at the DM's discretion. Such changes typically represent a fundamental shift in the creature's essence. For instance, an Oathbreaker might shift one of their affinities to {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, reflecting their altered nature and themes.

You gain mana during a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB} if you are in a location or near materials associated with your mana affinities. You determine the distribution of mana between your chosen affinities. If you cannot draw from your affinity types, or if you choose, you may instead gain {@variantrule 🔵 Blue Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}. Mana is used to activate abilities described in the respective mana rules.

The Pathfinder Mana System governs the use and recovery of mana within the manyverse. Creatures capable of accessing mana can store an amount equal to their level. Each turn, you can spend mana up to your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: 🟢 Green Mana
entries: See: {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}.

Green Mana oppresses {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, symbolizing growth and vitality overcoming entropy and decay. However, it is oppressed by {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, representing order and rationality constraining primal forces.

entries.name: 🔵 Blue Mana
entries: See: {@variantrule 🔵 Blue Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}.
Blue Mana is neutral and does not participate in the cycle of oppression. It often acts as a stabilizing or mediating force among the other mana types.

entries.name: ⚫ Black Mana
entries: See: {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}.

Black Mana oppresses {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, consuming its passion and vitality with entropy and inevitability. It is, however, oppressed by {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, which counters decay with growth and renewal.

entries.name: ⚪ White Mana
entries: See: {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}.

White Mana oppresses {@variantrule 🟢 Green Mana|CompendiumofAcadia} by overriding natural chaos and growth with mental constructs and rationality. However, it is oppressed by {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, which counters rigidity with raw passion and emotion.

entries.name: 🔴 Red Mana
entries: See: {@variantrule 🔴 Red Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}.

Red Mana oppresses {@variantrule ⚪ White Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, breaking through structure and order with chaos and passion. However, it is oppressed by {@variantrule ⚫ Black Mana|CompendiumofAcadia}, which consumes its vitality with entropy.

entries.name: Rules of Oppression

items: Oppress Elementals. After dealing damage to a Elemental, you can spend a Bonus action and 1 Mana immediately to deal 2d8 Radiant damage that ignores immunity and resistance.
Oppress Undeads. After dealing damage to a Undead, you can spend a Bonus action and 1 Mana immediately to deal 2d8 Elemental Damage of your choice damage that ignores immunity and resistance.
Oppress Humanoid. After dealing damage to a Humanoid, you can spend a Bonus action and 1 Mana immediately to deal 2d8 Necrotic damage that ignores immunity and resistance.
Oppress Celestials. After dealing damage to a Celetial, you can spend a Bonus action and 1 Mana immediately to deal 2d8 Physical Damage of your choice damage that ignores immunity and resistance.
Oppress Constructs. After dealing damage to a Construct, you can spend a Bonus action and 1 Mana immediately to deal 2d8 Force damage that ignores immunity and resistance.

variantrule.name: 🟢 Green Mana
entries: Green Mana embodies the primal forces that govern existence, thriving in the balance, growth, and unyielding will of nature. It sees reality as a product of these fundamental forces, which shape the world effortlessly and inherently, simply by their nature.
Green Mana can be drawn from various objects and locations that resonate with vitality, elemental force, and the spirit of life, such as:

items: Living Plants, Seeds, and Fruits brimming with vitality
Animal Totems, Amber and Spirit Relics
Natural Phenomena infused with elemental energy (e.g., lightning storms, or volcanic activity)
Man-made structures teeming with energy, like Power Plants, Wind Farms, and Hydroelectric Dams
Haunted Houses and locations charged with spiritual or elemental energy

Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Fire Bolt|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Shocking Grasp|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Acid Splash|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Ray of Frost|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Elementalism|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Components.

Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Burning Hands|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Witch Bolt|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Tasha's Caustic Brew|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Frost Fingers|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Absorb Elements|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Components.

Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Scorching Ray|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Warding Wind|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Melf's Acid Arrow|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Rime's Binding Ice|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Barkskin|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Components.

Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Fireball|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Lightning Bolt|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Erupting Earth|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Spirit Shroud|CompendiumOfAcadia} (cold damage option), or {@spell Elemental Weapon|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Components.

Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Conjure Minor Elementals|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Freedom of Movement|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Vitriolic Sphere|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Fire Shield|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Summon Elemental|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Components.

Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Conjure Elemental|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Destructive Wave|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Wall of Stone|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Cone of Cold|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Wrath of Nature|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Components.

variantrule.name: 🔵 Blue Mana
entries: Blue Mana represents self-reference, essential forms, and the interplay of paradoxes, embodying the ability to manipulate the foundational instructions of reality. It perceives differences as mere distortions or interpretations of a shared essence. For Blue Mana, existence is a web of interconnected truths, where every fragment reflects the whole.

Blue Mana can be drawn from virtually anything, as it exists in its raw and unaltered form throughout the multiverse. It is the neutral and foundational state of mana, the pure thread from which all other manifestations are woven.

items: Found wherever mana exists, as it is the primal essence underlying all forms of mana.
Arcane Affinity: Gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on an {@skill Arcana} check.
Fast Attunement: As a bonus action, you can attune or unattune to any number of magic items you have equipped. This does not allow you to exceed your normal attunement limit.
Spellcasting: You can cast {@spell Prestidigitation|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Mending|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Mage Hand|CompendiumOfAcadia}.

Arcane Hands: When casting a spell that requires somatic components, you can create arcane hands to perform them for you. This allows you to cast spells with somatic components even while holding weapons or a shield in one or both hands.
Essential Reduction: When dealing damage with a spell, you can change the damage type of the spell into Force damage.
Spellcasting: You can cast {@spell Find Familiar|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Mage Armor|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Magic Missile|CompendiumOfAcadia}.
Arcane Slash. As an Action, make a melee spell attack against a target within 10 feet. In a hit, it deals {@damage 3d10} Force damage.
Essential Protection. After getting hit by Force damage, reduce the Force damage by 4d4.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Misty Step|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Nystul's Magic Aura|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Wristpocket|CompendiumOfAcadia}.
Arcane Mount. You cast {@spell Phantom Steed|CompendiumOfAcadia} as a Action without verbal or somatic components.
Spell Resistance. After failing a saving throw against a spell, you can roll a d20 to substitute your roll, you have to take the last result.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Blink|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Counterspell|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Dispel Magic|CompendiumOfAcadia}.
Great Arcane Mount. You cast {@spell Find Greater Steed|CompendiumOfAcadia} as a Action without verbal or somatic components.
Arcane Jump. As a Action, you teleport yourself up 100 feet to a place you can see.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Banishment|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Mordenkainen's Faithful Hound|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Elemental Bane|CompendiumOfAcadia}
Arcane Creation. You cast {@spell Creation|CompendiumOfAcadia} as a Action without verbal or somatic components.

Essential Form Unleash As an Action, you unleash a powerful force within a 30-foot cube centered at a point up to 90 feet away. Each creature in the area must make a Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a creature takes 8d8 force damage and is {@condition Stunned} until the end of its next turn. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage and is not {@condition Stunned}.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Skill Empowerment|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Bigby's Hand|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Steel Wind Strike|CompendiumOfAcadia}.

variantrule.name: ⚫ Black Mana
entries: Black Mana embodies entropy, decay, and the inexorable pull of time and death. For Black Mana, reality is a constant flow of entropy, where chaos just increases inevitably. It represents the silent, inevitable end that awaits all things, drawing power from cycles of life and death, and the forces that bind existence to eventual entropy.
Black Mana can be drawn from various objects and locations that resonate with decay, darkness, and the inevitability of entropy, such as:

items: Ancient Cemeteries and Graveyards
Cursed Artifacts and Relics of Forgotten Ages
Places of Natural Decay, such as Swamps and Dead Forests
Astral Phenomena that embody chaos, such as Black Holes or Dying Stars
Man-made structures abandoned and overtaken by ruin, like Ghost Towns or Crumbling Temples
Negative Flow: When dealing Necrotic damage, deal an additional 1d8 Necrotic Damage.
Corpse Decay: As a bonus action, you can touch a body and make it crumble to dust.
Negate Healing: When dealing Necrotic damage, you can make a creature unable to recover hitpoints until the end on it's next turn.
Spellcasting: You can cast {@spell Toll the Dead |CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Spare the Dying|CompendiumOfAcadia}.
Entropy Healing: After getting healed, you can spend 2 hitdice and heal the amount rolled additionally.
Undead Nature. After taking poison damage, you can reduce the poison damage by half.
Gravitational Pull: As an Action, force a creature within 30 feet to make a Strength saving throw or be pulled 20 feet toward you.
Spellcasting: You can cast {@spell Ray of Sickness|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell False Life|CompendiumOfAcadia}.
Life Drain: As an Action, make a melee spell attack against a creature within 10 feet. On a hit, deal {@damage 3d6} necrotic damage and heal for half the damage dealt.
Warping Space. As an Action, you cast {@spell Vortex Warp|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Verbal or Somatic components.

Burden: As an Action, create a 30-foot-radius sphere of intensified gravity within 60 feet. Creatures in the area must make a Strength saving throw or have their movement reduced to 0 until the end of their next turn.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Immovable Object|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Ray of Enfeeblement|CompendiumOfAcadia}.

Necrotic Purge: As an Action, choose a creature within range, it makes a Constitution Saving Throw, taking 4d10 necrotic damage on a success, and half as much in a failure. Undead creatures take max damage from this.
Gravity Pulse: You cast {@spell Pulse Wave|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Verbal or Somatic components.
Fake Death: After taking damage, you can cast {@spell Feign Death|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Verbal, Somatic or Material components.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Life Transference|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Summon Undead|CompendiumOfAcadia}.
Gravitational Manifestation: You cast {@spell Gravity Sinkhole|CompendiumOfAcadia} without Verbal, Somatic or Material components.
Empower Undeath. When you create an undead, you have 40 points to distribute between then, their current and maximum hitpoints increases by that.
Necrotic Puppeteer: You cast {@spell Animate Dead|CompendiumOfAcadia} at 4th level with casting time of an Action and without Verbal, Somatic or Material Componenets.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Blight|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Consume Mind|CompendiumOfAcadia}.
Negative Energy Blade You cast {@spell Shadow Blade|CompendiumOfAcadia} at 5th level without componenets.

Undead Form. As an Action, you get 30 temporary hitpoints, for the next 10 minutes your creature type chanegs to Undead, you are immune to Poison damage, immune to Exhaustion and Poisoned conditions. Eveytime you deal damage, it's increased by 5 necrotic damage. Advantage on Constitution saves, and everytime you are reduced to 0 HP, you make a DC 5 + damage taken Constitution Saving Throw, being reduced to 1 instead of 0 if you pass, this does not apply if the damage that reduced you to 0 was radiant or from a critical. After this effect ends you take 3 levels of exhaustion.

Great Kiss of Death. As an Action, choose a creature within 5 feet. It makes a Constitution Saving Throw, in a failure it takes {@damage 10d10} Necrotic damage. A creature that died by this crumbles until nothing is left.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Negative Energy Flood|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Contagion|CompendiumOfAcadia}.

variantrule.name: ⚪ White Mana
entries: White Mana embodies order, rationality, and the supremacy of the mind. It is the power of laws, knowledge, and oaths, drawing from the belief that reality is shaped by the constructs of thought. For White Mana, the physical world is not the foundation of existence but the reflection of mental and conceptual frameworks.
White Mana can be drawn from various objects and locations imbued with intellectual and symbolic significance, such as:

items: Academic Books and Scrolls
Oaths, Contracts, and Symbols of Authority (e.g., seals, badges, ceremonial objects)
Sacred Texts, and Religious Manuscripts
Writing Materials (paper, quills, ink)
Libraries, Archives, and Halls of Learning

Replicate Information. As an Magic Action, You can replicate written text at 1 minute per page or images at 60 times the normal speed, provided you have the necessary tools and materials. You must concentrate as if on a spell and can maintain this for up to 1 hour. You may replicate text accurately or in your own style. This also applies to copying spells into your spellbook, taking 1 minute per spell level.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Vicious Mockery|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell True Strike|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Light|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Message|CompendiumOfAcadia}.

Sharp Mind. As an Magic Action, you gain perfect recall and clarity for 8 hours, allowing you to remember anything you’ve seen or heard during this time. You also have advantage on Arcana, History, Nature, and Religion checks.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Charm Person|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Comprehend Languages|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Detect Magic|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Identify|CompendiumOfAcadia}.
Truth Bastion As an action, you create a 15-foot radius Emanation that functions as the {@spell Zone of Truth|CompendiumOfAcadia} spell, that lasts for 1 hour.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Borrowed Knowledge|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Calm Emotions|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Detect Thoughts|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Invisibility|CompendiumOfAcadia}.
Vibrating Vision. As an Action, for the next 8 hours, you have {@sense Tremorsense|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Clairvoyance|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Intellect Fortress|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Tongues|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Fear|CompendiumOfAcadia}.

Powerful Message. As an Action, you send a telepathic message to a target within 60 feet, choosing one of the following:
• Memory. Show a willing target a memory of yours (up to 10 minutes long), remembered perfectly for 1 hour.
• Message: Deliver a message of up to 100 words, remembered perfectly for 1 hour.
• Terror Image: The target makes a Wisdom saving throw, taking {@damage 6d10} Psychic damage on a failure, or half as much on a success.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Arcane Eye|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Charm Monster|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Divination|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Hallucinatory Terrain|CompendiumOfAcadia}.

Awaken Mind. As an Action, you target a object or a willing creature no larger than Large. If its Intelligence is below 10, it becomes 10, and it learns a language you know if it doesn’t speak any. An object gains stats as an {@creature Animated Object|XPHB} with 10 Intelligence (choose Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma as its modifier if you lack a spellcasting ability) or another stat block like {@creature Awakened Shrub|XMM} or {@creature Awakened Tree|XMM}, as the DM decides. This lasts until dispelled. The target is Charmed for 30 days or until harmed by you or your allies, after which it chooses its attitude toward you.
Spellcasting: Cast {@spell Commune|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Dominate Person|CompendiumOfAcadia}, {@spell Modify Memory|CompendiumOfAcadia}, or {@spell Scrying|CompendiumOfAcadia}.

variantrule.name: 🔴 Red Mana
entries: Red Mana embodies the raw, untamed power of passion, emotion, and willpower. It thrives in the flames of determination and the relentless strength found in every living being. For Red Mana, reality is not a fixed construct but a dynamic canvas shaped by the intensity of desires and the sheer force of emotions brought to life.
Red Mana can be harnessed from objects, practices, and locations that resonate with resolve, emotional intensity, and physical expression, including:

items: Training Grounds and Arenas
Weapons and Combat Tools
Symbols of Passion and Emotion
Manifestations of Emotion (e.g., demons)
Dance Halls and Musical Places
You get 1d8 bonus to your initiative.
You cast {@spell Blade Ward|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
You gain 20 feet of movement until the end of this turn.
You gain advantage on a {@skill Intimidation}, {@skill Performance}, or {@skill Persuasion} check.
You gain Advantage on {@skill History}, {@skill Investigation}, or {@skill Insight} check.
You cast {@spell Compelled Duel|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
You take a Bonus action, immediately after hitting a target with a Melee weapon or an Unarmed Strike, it deals 2d8 additional damage of the same type.
You cast {@spell Heroism|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
When taking damage from a attack that deals Bludgeoning, Piercing, or Slashing damage, you can use your Reaction to you reduce the damage by 2d8.
You cast {@spell Jump|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
You cast {@spell Arcane Vigor|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
You cast {@spell Enhance Ability|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
You cast {@spell Kinetic Jaunt|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
After you make a weapon attack against a target, you can take an additional attack against a target up to 5 feet of it if inside your range
If a creature trigger a opportinity attack against you, you can make this attack with a bonus of 2d8 on the attack and damage.
You cast {@spell Haste|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
You cast {@spell Motivational Speech|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
At yhe start of your turn, for the next hour, your movement speed increases by 20 feet.
As a Action, you make a unarmed strike against the target within 10 feet, on a hit it deals 7d10 bludgeoning damage.
After failing a Strength, Constitution or Dexterity save, you can roll 2d8 and add to the check, potentially turning it into a success.
You cast {@spell Freedom of Movement|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
You cast {@spell Enlarge/Reduce|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
As an Action, you gain Advantage in Strength, Dexterity and Constitution saving throws and ability checks for the next hour.
You cast {@spell Haste|CompendiumOfAcadia}, but you do not need to concetrate on the spell.
You cast {@spell Stoneskin|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
You cast {@spell Circle of Power|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.
You cast {@spell Banishing Smite|CompendiumOfAcadia} without components.

As a reaction for being affected by a curse, exhaustion levels, Charmed or petrified condition, reduction to ability scores or reduction of maximum hitpoints, you cast {@spell Greater Restoration|CompendiumOfAcadia} on Self without components.
You get an additional Action this turn, except a magic action. Immediatelly before taking it, you take 4d12 necrotic damage that cannot be reduced or negated in any way.
Undertaker. As a Action, you make 6 unnarmed strikes against targets withing 10 feet, each of then deals 2d8 bludgeoning damage on a hit.

variantrule.name: Luck Rolls
entries: Luck Rolls are rolls made when an event's outcome is determined primarily by luck or chance, rather than skill or direct action.
These rolls can include modifiers but are not considered d20 Tests.
An example of a Luck Roll is determining whether a Wand of Magic Missiles breaks after expending all charges. Or the roll made for choosing witch Ray the beholder will shoot.

variantrule.name: Enhanced Foods
entries: Specially prepared foods provide adventurers with unique benefits during their journeys.
A character with the {@feat Chef|XPHB} feat can create a Meal using 'Replenishing Meal' instead of its default Meal, or a Treat using 'Bolstering Treat' instead of its default Treat.

A creature can benefit from up to two food effects at the same time. If it consumes a new food that grants a food effect while already at the limit, it must choose whether to keep one of the current effects or replace it with the new one.
Food effects expire after a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.
There are two types of foods:

items: Snacks: Consumed with a bonus action, providing short-term benefits.
Meals: Require at least 10 minutes to consume, offering more lasting and impactful effects.

entries: Here are some example foods and their effects:

entries.caption: Enhanced Foods
rows: Gain temporary hit points equal to your proficiency bonus.
Gain advantage on the next saving throw you make until the end of your next turn.
Gain a +1d4 bonus to your next attack roll until the end of your next turn.
Gain 10 feet of additional movement until the end of your next turn.
Add +1d8 to the total hit points recovered when spending Hit Dice during a Short Rest.
Gain +1d6 to add to a Strength, Dexterity, or Constitution {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}. Effect expires after use.
Gain +1d6 to add to a Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}. Effect expires after use.
Gain {@variantrule Advantage|XPHB} on Constitution Saving Throws against Exhaustion or environmental effects (e.g., extreme heat or cold).

variantrule.name: Universal Spell Scrolls
entries: When scribing Spell Scrolls, a spellcaster can choose to make it a Universal Spell Scroll. This type of scroll can be used by any creature that understands any language, even if the spell is not on their spell list.

If the creature does not have a spell list, or if the spell on the scroll is of a higher level than they can normally cast, they must make an ability check to cast the spell, as described in the Spell Scroll rules. If the creature is not a spellcaster, it can choose Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma for the check.

A creature can spend 1 hour studying a Universal Spell Scroll and familiarizing itself with its casting process. After doing so, it adds its proficiency bonus to the ability check to determine whether you cast the spell. This familiarity lasts until the creature takes a Long Rest.

variantrule.name: Alternate Spell Casting
entries: All spells require both Verbal and Somatic components. However, Bonus Action spells require only one of these components, chosen by the caster. Material components (M) follow standard rules.

variantrule.name: Casting Constraints
entries: If a creature is {@condition Grappled}, {@condition Prone}, or {@condition Restrained} and attempts to cast a spell that requires somatic components, it must succeed on a DC 10 Concentration check.
On a failure, the spell does not take effect, but the spell slot is not expended.
